Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Autonomous Self-Healing of Commodity Acrylic Copolymers
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Polymers exhibit a wealth of useful properties that make these materials uniquely applicable for a broad range of applications in all areas of technology and society. If commodity polymers were capable of self-repair upon fracture, many new applications could be sought out, enabling long-lasting properties, new functions, and substantial savings. This project seeks to understand the observed self-healing behavior in a type of commodity polymers (acrylate-based copolymers) which, in a certain intermediate compositional range undergo remarkable autonomous repair upon mechanical damage. If this unexplained observation is understood at a molecular level, it may offer high scientific and technological payoffs. This project will also explore the design of new copolymers with self-healing properties, which would reduce their consumption and have positive ecological impacts. This new fundamental knowledge may be used to explore other commodity polymers and at the same time train students in an interdisciplinary manner and prepare them to tackle global technological challenges.



TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This project aims to elucidate molecular origins of a surprising self-healing in commodity poly(methyl methacrylate/n-butyl acrylate), p(MMA/nBA), copolymers. This will be pursued by precisely synthesizing alternating, random, and block copolymers in the 45/55 - 55/45 MMA/nBA molar compositional range, correlating with the extent of self-healing, and identifying molecular events that govern this unique behavior. For that purpose, narrow dispersity copolymers with variable block sizes will be synthesized using atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP) and heterogeneous radical polymerization (HRP). These experiments will allow to determine the role of the neighboring MMA and nBA copolymer repeating units on conformational changes during the damage-repair cycle and subsequent self-repair. The role of free radicals which can be potentially generated during mechanical damage as a function of copolymer molecular weight and copolymer topologies, and particularly their role in rebonding, will also be investigated. Since chain cleavage and/or slippage are expected to be copolymer-composition dependent, to identify molecular events responsible for self-healing, in-situ surface/interfacial chemical imaging (IR/Raman), electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy will be utilized. If intrinsic free radicals are generated during mechanical damage, they will act as dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP) agents to selectively enhance the magic-angle spinning (MAS) NMR signals of nuclei at the damage site. These measurements will be conducted as a function of copolymer topology, molecular weight, and dispersity, and will provide information about specific atomic-level conformation of the polymer chains, concentration levels of free radicals, and the nature of chemical groups at the site of damage. The planned experimental studies will parallel molecular dynamics simulations which will examine the role of van der Waals and other interactions on copolymer topologies and self-healing behavior.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Self-healing is the capability of a material to recover from physical damage. This research has led to the development of commodity plastics that exhibit self-healing properties. Because these inexpensive materials are capable of autonomous self-healing, they will impact fields of polymer and materials science, polymer engineering and processing as well as related fields to become technologically feasible enterprise in many technological sectors. Furthermore, this project developed protocols how to design sustainable polymers by imbedding self-healing functions which find numerous applications in the energy, healthcare, and homeland security sectors, all of which are vital to US global competitiveness. Its significance and importance lies in the fact that by addressing fundamental scientific questions commodity plastics equipped with self-healing functions became sustainable and will minimize ‘the great Pacific garbage patch.’ Through the integration of research and education, a new generation of diversified graduate students supported by NSF funding have become productive members of our society.

In terms of intellectual merit, the unique self-healing behavior was attributed to favorable inter-chain van der Waals (vdW) forces forming 'key-and-lock' inter-chain junctions. Outside  self-healable compositional range as well as for block copolymers, self-healing does not occur. The main feature of vdW interactions is large polarizability (hydrophobicity) which in thermoplastic polymers leads to non-directional interactions between neighboring macromolecular segments, thus energetically favoring closer chain proximity. If dipole-dipole directionality of the side groups is facilitated by alternating/random copolymer compositions, inter-chain vdW forces will increase. Thus, upon mechanical damage macromolecular segments will energetically favor original inter-chain conformations and return to their original conformations resulting in self-healing. To illustrate how directionality of copolymer chain side-groups and their orientations affect one can draw analogy to highly ordered layered systems with large individual atomic planes, in which attractive forces in two-dimensional materials (e.g., graphene, inorganics, others) are highly directional, thus resulting in collectively stronger bonding.

The broader impact of these studies are the development of scientific methodologies to pursue these research goals and methods to collect and analyze reliable data. These included an array of spectroscopic tools combined with mechanical testing and spectroscopic imaging. One provisional patent was submitted, one publication was published (Urban, et al, Science, 2018, 362, 220?225), and significant industrial and government interests have been generated. These studeis were featured by DMR NSF website (https://www.nsf.gov/news/news_summ.jsp?cntn_id=296972&org=DMR&from=news). The outcomes of this project also attracted industrial partners and collaborations with the national lab scientists because the ability of commodity polymers to self-heal will significantly reduce costly maintenance and enhance safety in construction, transport, energy, and biomedical sectors.

Modified by: Marek W Urban
